titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Tully Family Papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid by Todd A. Lane and Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 03:00

did.unittitle: Tully Family Papers

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

did.abstract: William Tully (1785-1859) was professor of materia medica and therapeutics at the Medical Institution of Yale College from 1824 to 1842. The collection contains a small amount of correspondence by or to Tully and limited material on Tully's medical career. One subseries concerns settling the estate of William Tully and finding funds to support his daughters Sarah and Elizabeth. The collection contains genealogies, original documents of the Tully family in Connecticut, and also documents related to ancestors of Tully's wife, Mary Potter Tully, particularly her father, the Rev. Elam Potter, and her stepfather, the Rev. Nehemiah Prudden. Photographs include daguerrotypes of Tully's children.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Harry B. Ferris, M.D., professor of anatomy at Yale University School of Medicine, obtained this material in 1930 along with some of Tully's furniture from the woman who let rooms to Elizabeth Tully in Springfield, Massachusetts, before her death in 1915. He donated the papers to the Beaumont Medical Club in 1934. They are on permanent deposit in the Historical Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Some items are too fragile to copy.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is in the public domain.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Tully Family Papers, Historical Library, Cushing/Whitney Medical Library, Yale University

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Tully was born on November 18, 1785, the son of Colonel William and Eunice Tully of Saybrook, Connecticut. He graduated from Yale College in 1806. In the spring of 1807, Tully began studying medicine with Mason F. Cogswell of Hartford and in the fall of that year traveled to New Hampshire to study medicine with Nathan Smith at Dartmouth College. Upon his return to Connecticut in 1810, Tully studied under Samuel Carter and entered the office of Eli Ives, later professor of materia medica at Yale. Tully was licensed to practice by the Connecticut Medical Society in 1810 and opened an office in Enfield, Connecticut in 1811. In 1813, he married Mary Potter of Enfield. Tully lived and practiced for several years in Middletown, Connecticut, where he co-authored with Dr. Thomas Miner a book, Essays on Fevers, and Other Medical Subjects (1823). From 1824 to 1830 he was president and professor of medical practice and jurisprudence at the Vermont Academy of Medicine, in Castleton, Vermont. While at Castleton he was appointed professor of materia medica and therapeutics at the Medical Institution of Yale College and moved to New Haven; however he remained on the staff of the Vermont Academy until 1838. Tully resigned his chair at Yale in 1842 and eventually moved to Springfield, Massachusetts, where he lived with his two unmarried daughters, Sarah and Elizabeth. He continued his practice and taught at the Berkshire Medical Institution in Pittsfield, Massachusetts. Late in his career, he published Materia Medica, or Pharmacology and Therapeutics (1857-58). He died in Springfield in on February 28, 1859, predeceased by his wife and survived by only three of their eleven children, Sarah, William, and Elizabeth. Sarah and Elizabeth continued to live together in Springfield after their father's death.

The Tully family came to New England from England in the 1640s. Tully's grandfather, William Tully of Saybrook married Elizabeth Lay and had three daughters and a son, Col. William Tully (1758-1811). Col. Tully married his cousin Eunice Tully (1758-1815) and had only one child, William Tully (1785-1859) who became a physician. Dr. William Tully's wife, Mary Potter (1791-1853), was the daughter of the Rev. Elam Potter (1742-1794) of Enfield and Sibyl Pease Potter (1754-1822). Some time after 1799, Sybil Potter was married again to the Rev. Nehemiah Prudden of Enfield, then a widower.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of a small amount of personal correspondence of William Tully, memoranda, receipts, and wills. There is considerable material on the settling of Tully's estate, especially correspondence of the executor, Dr. Edwin Seeger. Seeger and others arranged for the sale of Tully's books by auction and tried to have his manuscripts (now unlocated) published. Among the estate papers are notes on patients who still owed money to Tully. The correspondence of Sarah and Elizabeth Tully in the collection mostly concerns the estate, financial matters, and family. The family part of the collection relates to the ancestry of the Tully, Potter, Pease, and Prudden families. There are Tully land deeds going back to the seventeenth century, a Bible signed by "John Tulley" in 1667, notes on scriptures by the Rev. Elam Potter, and two sermons by the Rev. Nehemiah Prudden of Enfield, as well as genealogical material and early documents related to the families. Photographs include twelve daguerrotypes of Tully's children, including of Hephzibah Tully who died in 1849.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in four series: 1. William Tully (1785-1859) and immediate family. 2. Tully family ancestors. 3. Potter, Pease, and Prudden families. 4. Photographs and miscellany.

did.unittitle: William Tully (1785-1859) and immediate family
Correspondence, Writings, Receipts
Letters by William Tully
Letter, New Haven, to [Dr. Cornelius S. Baker]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft of a letter to a suitor to one of his daughters. The recipient is probably Dr. Cornelius S. Baker who later married Tully's daughter, Eunice, on January 26, 1836.

did.unittitle: To Dr. Hazen, Middletown - typed transcript of a letter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On making Tully's Compound Powder of Camphor as a substitute for Dover's Powder. Tully does not know which Middletown Hazen is from, but sends his letter to Middletown, Connecticut. The original letter is not in the collection.

did.unittitle: Letter, Pittsfield, Massachusetts, to Edwin Seeger, M.D., Springfield, Massachusetts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tully is in Pittsfield, Massachusetts. Letter discusses his giving lectures and whether the students are prepared well enough by Dr. Childs. Discusses his own health.

did.unittitle: Letters to William Tully
From Daniel Bontecue, Springfield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To Tully in New Haven on the death of Tully's daughter Catherine and the death of his own daughter.

did.unittitle: From Cornelius L. Baker, "Churchville"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To Tully in New Haven regarding his daughter Eunice Tully.

did.unittitle: From S. M. Tully, Saybrook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sends Mr. Pratt's acount.

did.unittitle: From J. Barnes, Middletown

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: To Tully in New Haven concerning accounts.

did.unittitle: From Edward C. Herrick, New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Herrick handled legal affairs for the Tully family. He requests information on the type of stone and inscription for the grave, probably for Mary Tully, Dr. Tully's wife, who died in September 1853.

did.unittitle: R. E. Pratt, Saybrook, to William Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Financial and personal.

did.unittitle: From J. Branch, "Abbeville"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Is replying belatedly to Tully's letter. A physician friend will visit Tully in Springfield. Tully had died February 28, 1859.

did.unittitle: From T. F. Welch, Milford

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning a prescription that Tully gave him.

did.unittitle: From Frances A. Clarke

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Incomplete letter with envelope addressed to William Tully in Springfield "per Miss Elizabeth L. Tully." On reverse is a pencil transcription from the tombstone of the Rev. Elam Potter (1742-1794), father of William Tully's wife.

did.unittitle: Early documents concerning Mary Potter Tully, wife of Dr.William Tully
Legal document of money owed by Elam O. Potter to Mary Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Elam O. Potter was Mary Potter Tully's brother. William Tully wrote on the document,"This bond is cancelled by a transfer of these shares. Wm Tully." He referred to stock of the Hartford Bank.

did.unittitle: Certification by Nehemiah Prudden, rector of the church in Enfield, that Mrs. Mary Tully is a member in good standing
Survey of the division of the property of the estate of Capt. Ephraim Pease, Enfield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Copy" but appears contemporary. Capt. Pease was Mary Tully's grandfather. One portion went to William and Mary Tully.

did.unittitle: Thomas Miner and William Tully, An Examination of the Strictures in the New England Journal for October, 1823 and in the North American Reviwew... on Essays on Fevers, & c. (Middletown, CT: Printed by E. & H. Clarke, 1823)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet in response to the published critiques of Thomas Miner and William Tullly, Essays on Fevers and Other Medical Subjects (Middletown, CT: Printed and published by E. & H. Clark, 1823).

did.unittitle: "Books taken for Yale College"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: List of books with prices. Presumably Tully sold some of his books to Yale.

did.unittitle: Agreeement with Jefferson Church of Springfield, Massachusetts, to publish Tully's book on materia medica

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Tully's Materia medica; or, Pharmacology and therapeutics, 2 vols. was published by J. Church, Springfield in 1857-1858. Tully transferred copyright to Church.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous memoranda by William Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mostly financial.

did.unittitle: William Tully receipts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some receipts relate to the deaths of Sarah Tully (sister of grandfather) in 1830 and of Catherine Tully (daughter) in 1833.

did.unittitle: William Tully receipts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes three bills for money owed by patients, 1851-1856. See also Box 1, folder 13.

did.unittitle: Will of Mary Tully, New Haven (Copy) and other materials concerning her death

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mary Tully, wife of Dr. William Tully, died September 8, 1853. The copy of her will left the residue of her personal property to Edward C. Herrick, New Haven, to be held by him in trust for her surviving children, Sarah, Elizabeth Lay, and William. Also includes "Estate of Mrs. Mary Tully in Account with L. A. Thomas," n.d.; and "Edwd. C. Herrick, trustee of estate of Mary Tully," n.d.

did.unittitle: Wills of William Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: His will of December 14, 1857 left his property to his three surviving children, Sarah, Elizabeth, and William. Edwin Seeger, M.D. of Springfield was appointed executor.

did.unittitle: William Tully's estate and his immediate family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William Tully M.D. died February 28, 1859 in Springfield, Massachusetts, where he was living with his two daughters, Sarah (1817-1901) and Elizabeth (1830-1915). He was also survived by a son, William (1830-1880), who married in 1860. The settling of Tully's estate is well documented in these papers. Though William received some assets, the overwhelming concern was to find enough money to support the two unmarried daughters throughout their lives.

did.unittitle: Monies owed by and to the estate of William Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These bills were collected by Edwin Seeger, M.D. of Springfield, Tully's executor. Included is a list of money donated to Sarah and Elizabeth Tully in memory of William Tully, by various people including Yale medical professors.

did.unittitle: Money owed to the estate by patients of William Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included are eight bills for medical visits and treatments by Tully and a list of patients owing money. These cover the period 1851-1857. Annotations in pencil state whether payment will be received.

did.unittitle: Letters of Edward C. Herrick to Edwin Seeger concerning the estate of William Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns a catalogue of Tully's library that Herrick had prepared, and plans for the sale of Tully's books.

did.unittitle: Letters of George A. Leavitt & Co., Auctioneers, to Edwin Seeger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerns the auction of William Tully's books in New York. Beinecke Library holds a copy of the sale catalog. See Catalogue of an extensive collection of scientific, medical and miscellaneous books, being the private library of the late Dr. Wm. Tully ... : which will be sold at auction ... (New York: George A. Leavitt & Co., [1859])

did.unittitle: Letters of Henry F. Fish, Waterbury, and F. L. Fish to Edwin Seeger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Henry F. Fish and his successors were insurers and friends of the Tully family. There are two letters from Henry F. Fish to George A. Leavitt & Co. Henry F. Fish hoped to obtain money for the estate from the publication of Tully's manuscripts.

did.unittitle: Other letters to Edwin Seeger, executor

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From S. B. Baker, William R. Clarke, Hampden Fire Insurance Co., Samuel Noyes, and R. E. Pratt, Lucas A. Thomas, H. A. Tilden, and Sarah Tully.

did.unittitle: Marriage certificate of William Tully and Elizabeth King of New London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plus contemporary copy.

did.unittitle: Letters of Edward C. Herrick to Mary Tully, and then to Sarah and Elizabeth Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters concern income from property he is managing from the estates of Mary Tully and later William Tully.

did.unittitle: Letters of Fish & Lee, Myron H. Fish, and William T. Fish to Sarah and Elizabeth Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The letters are partly financial and partly personal. One letter is on Aetna letterhead.

did.unittitle: Letters of L.Watson, M.D. to Sarah Tully concerning possible publication of William Tully's manuscripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a circular by Henry F. Fish, Waterbury, requesting Tully manuscripts for the purpose. His manuscripts do not seem to have been published.

did.unittitle: Letters to Sarah and Elizabeth Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also included are a few financial memoranda, 1870-1878.

did.unittitle: Draft will of Sarah Tully and report of estate by Elizabeth Tully, executrix, 1911

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sarah Tully died in 1901. The draft will is undated. There is also an unsigned draft by Sarah Tully appointing Myron H. Fish her attorney, 1858.

did.unittitle: Letters, postcards, and greeting cards to Elizabeth Tully
Letters to Elizabeth Tully and materials from religious institutions
Elizabeth Tully bank accounts and stock investments

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes circulars to stockholders from the Consolidated Alaskan Co., 1900-1904, the Springfield Street Railway Co., 1900, and other companies.

did.unittitle: Newspaper clippings, religious poetry, and miscellanea

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The clippings and religious poetry were presumably collected by Elizabeth Tully. They include some newspaper obituaries.

did.unittitle: Tully family ancestors
Tully family genealogy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Members of the Tully family came from England to New England in 1646 or 1647. Dr. William Tully's grandfather, William Tully, married Elizabeth Lay and had three daughters and a son, also William. This Col. William Tully of Saybrook (1759-1811) married his cousin Eunice Tully (1758-1815) in 1785 and had only one child, Dr. William Tully (1785-1859).

did.unittitle: "Tully Record": genealogy of the Tully family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This bound journal was written in the nineteenth century. William Tully's death (1859) and the death of his son William (1880) and daughter Sarah (1901) were added later in pencil, probably by his daughter Elizabeth, whose death in 1915 is not noted. Includes note from H. B. Ferris on the provenance of this book.

did.unittitle: Tully family genealogy by William Tully, M.D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also an additional genealogical list in pencil.

did.unittitle: Notes on early Tully genealogy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On the early history of the Tully family, written in response to an article in the New Haven Palladium, 1880, on documents found in Fanueil Hall, Boston. Author is not identified.

did.unittitle: Tully family graves

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Information and inscriptions on graves, each written as separate notes. Some of these notes were written by Dr. William Tully. Includes a partial key to the family graves at Grove Street Cemetery, New Haven.

did.unittitle: Early Tully family documents
Bible owned and signed by "John Tulley," London, 1667

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed Bible is missing its title page and is unidentified. In back is a note of the donation of the Bible to the Medical Library by Mrs. H. B. Ferris, 1941. Inserted is a small needlework of a church.

did.unittitle: Deed from Robert Lay of Saybrook to "John Tulley" of Saybrook
"John Tulley, Sr." of Saybrook, to Mr. Harris

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning books that Harris sent him. Tulley requested an almanac.

did.unittitle: Will of William Tully of Saybrook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He appears to have died in 1775. Will signed by John and Samuel Tully.

did.unittitle: Special town meeting, Saybrook, 1777

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On soldiers and ammunition for the Revolutionary War and on division of property. The Tullys are not mentioned.

did.unittitle: Letters from William Tully, Saybrook, to his sister Hephzibah Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2 items. This William Tully was Dr. William Tully's father. He writes to his sister on the illness and death of their mother, Elizabeth Lay Tully. The second letter also contains a letter to Joseph Utley requesting that he come to Saybrook on behalf of Elisha Utley who is dangerously ill. William asks Hephzibah to convey the message.

did.unittitle: Tully family deeds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Some of the deeds relate to Dr. William Tully.

did.unittitle: Potter, Pease, and Prudden families

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series relates to the ancestors of Dr. William Tully's wife, Mary Potter Tully (1791-1853), particularly the Potter, Prudden families. Mary Tully was the daughter of the Rev. Elam Potter and Sybil Pease Potter. The Rev. Elam Potter (1742-1794) preached in Enfield, Connecticut. Sybil Pease Potter (1754-1822) was the daughter of Capt. Ephraim Pease and Tabitha Abby. Some time after 1799, she married the widower Rev. Nathaniel Prudden, successor to the Rev. Elam Potter as minister in Enfield.

did.unittitle: "Potter record": notes on Potter genealogy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covers the period from 1668 to 1865.

did.unittitle: Notes on scriptures by the Rev. Elam Potter

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Very fragile handwritten notes on Bible passages, most undated.

did.unittitle: "Extracts from Journal of the Rev. Elam Potter copied from the original manuscript"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: It is unclear when these pencil copies were made and where the original journal is located. The one date included is 1766.

did.unittitle: "Some circumstances of the sickness and death of the Rev. Elam Potter of Enfield Ct..." (copy?)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rev. Elam Potter died on Long Island January 5, 1794. This six-page handwritten account was possibly by Potter's son, Elam O. Potter.

did.unittitle: Letter of Sibyl Pease Potter to Elam O. Potter
Two original sermons by the Rev. Nehemiah Prudden of Enfield
"Pease record"/ Pease-Prudden family notes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The "Pease record," possibly by William Tully, lists the immediate descendents of Captain Ephraim Pease (1720-1801) and includes epitaphs. The Pease-Prudden notes were "copied from Mrs. Prudden's funeral sermon, Feb, 16th 1799" on the back of an 1899 calendar page.

did.unittitle: Notice of Elam O. Potter's Public House, Wallingford, Connecticut
Photographs and miscellany
Photographs of William Tully portraits and of the Tully birthplace in Saybrook, Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photographs of the home, built by Tully's grandfather ca. 1750, were taken in 1930. Includes negatives.

did.unittitle: Daguerrotypes and cabinet photographs of children of Dr. William Tully and Mary Potter Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The envelopes for these items have been numbered.

did.unittitle: 1. Daguerrotype of William Tully, Jr. (1830-1880)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Civil War uniform.

did.unittitle: 2. Daguerrotype of Elizabeth King Tully, wife of William Tully, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She was married to William Tully, son of Dr. William Tully, in 1860.

did.unittitle: 3-5. Daguerrotypes of Sarah Tully (1815-1901)
6. Daguerrotype of William Tully, Jr.
7. Daguerrotype of William and Elizabeth Lay Tully (1830-1915)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: William and Elizabeth Lay, twins born in 1830, were the last children of Dr. William Tully and Mary Potter Tully. Dr. William Tully's grandmother was Elizabeth Lay.

did.unittitle: 8. Daguerrotype of William (son) and Elizabeth Lay Tully
9. Daguerrotype probably of Elizabeth Lay Tully

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No cover.

did.unittitle: 10. Daguerrotype of Hephzibah Tully (1816-1849)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: No cover.

did.unittitle: 11-12. Daguerrotype of Hephzibah Tully (2 copies)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Smaller format.

did.unittitle: Studio cards of Sarah Tully and Elizabeth King Tully
Envelope of small keys
